segments.text: So it is hard to be a black student on campus ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Yes , in many ways it is . There are many stereotypes I have to deal with in my daily life .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: Well , like since I'm black , I must like rap music , come from the inner city , or play basketball well .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I do know you like rap music , but the other two are definitely false . I â€™ Ve seen you play basketball .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Hey ! But that's not the only problem . There's also the affirmative action stigma .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: You mean that people look down upon you because they think you're in school because of a quota ? That's not true at all , you're really a smart guy .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: I know that , but some people don't think like that . And I get problems from teachers as well .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: Teachers ? I didn't think that they would be racist at all .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Racist ? Not exactly . It's how they look at me and ask for my opinion on a topic , as if I can speak for all black people and give them the black opinion on a subject . Suddenly I become the representative of the black race , as if we all had the same opinion .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I see . It looks like there are still a lot of issues we need to work on in the US .
segments.speaker: S1
